text: If you're more in the people pleasing camp, maybe you're used to not asking at all. You're hoping that people are reading your mind. And if you're sort of more in the control freak camp, maybe you're used to ordering people around and saying, "Go do this now."
speaker: Kenneth Berger
context: Lenny asks Kenneth how people can know if they need to work on asking for what they want. Kenneth explains that there are two common problematic approaches people take when they struggle with this skill. He identifies that people typically fall into one of two camps when it comes to making requests - either they avoid asking entirely and expect others to intuitively understand their needs, or they become overly controlling and demanding in their communication style.
text_ko: 사람들 기쁘게 하려는 편이라면 아예 묻지 않는 데 익숙할 거예요. 사람들이 내 마음을 읽어주길 바라고 있죠. 반대로 통제하려는 편이라면 사람들에게 지시해서 “이거 지금 해”라고 말하는 게 더 익숙할 거예요.
text_zh: 如果你比较喜欢讨好别人，可能你根本就不习惯开口要求什么。你总是希望别人能猜到你在想什么。要是你偏向控制狂那一类，可能你习惯了指挥别人，张口就是"赶紧去做这个"。
text_es: Si eres más del tipo que siempre quiere quedar bien con todos, probablemente estés acostumbrado a no pedir nada directamente. Andas esperando que la gente te lea la mente. Y si eres más del tipo controlador obsesivo, tal vez estés acostumbrado a darle órdenes a todo el mundo y decirles "Ve y haz esto ahora mismo."

text: Complaints are great inspiration. Every complaint implies a dream. Let me envision a better future. Let me think about what's an effective way to actually move towards that. See what it's like to not be sort of living in fear all the time.
speaker: Kenneth Berger
context: Lenny asks Kenneth how people can figure out what they want in their lives and careers, especially for those who struggle with knowing their own desires. Kenneth introduces a technique he calls "dream behind the complaint" - the idea that people are often better at complaining than dreaming, but every complaint contains valuable information about what they actually want. He suggests using complaints as starting points to envision better futures and develop effective strategies to achieve them.
text_ko: 불만은 훌륭한 영감이에요. 모든 불만에는 더 나은 무언가를 바라는 꿈이 담겨 있어요. 제가 더 나은 미래를 상상하게 해줘요. 그리고 그걸 실제로 향해 나아가게 할 효과적인 방법이 무엇인지 생각하게 해줘요. 늘 두려움에 사로잡혀 살지 않는 삶이 어떤지 느껴보게 해줘요.
text_zh: 客户抱怨其实是很好的灵感来源。每一个抱怨背后都藏着一个期待，让我去想象一个更好的未来。让我想想怎么才能真正有效地朝那个方向努力。看看不用总是提心吊胆过日子是什么感觉。
text_es: Las quejas son una inspiración increíble. Cada queja esconde un sueño. Déjame imaginar un futuro mejor. Déjame pensar en cuál sería una manera efectiva de realmente avanzar hacia eso. Ver cómo sería no estar viviendo con miedo todo el tiempo.

text: Often what I try to introduce people to, and I've learned all this stuff the hard way, believe me, is it's fundamentally disrespectful to go into a meeting already deciding that you're right and the other person is wrong because you can't know that for sure. There's always a new perspective, new data that could come in.
speaker: Kenneth Berger
context: Lenny asks Kenneth for an example from his own career where he failed to ask for what he wanted effectively. Kenneth reflects on his tendency to be overly attached to being right, particularly in his product management role. He explains how this mindset of entering conversations with predetermined conclusions about being correct is not only ineffective but also disrespectful to others, as it prevents genuine dialogue and learning from new information.
text_ko: 제가 사람들에게 자주 전하려고 하는 말인데요, 이건 저도 뼈저리게 배운 거예요. 회의에 들어가서 이미 '내가 옳고 네가 틀렸다'고 단정해 버리는 건 근본적으로 상대에 대한 무례예요. 왜냐하면 그걸 확실히 알 수는 없으니까요. 언제든 새로운 관점이나 추가적인 데이터가 들어올 수 있어요.
text_zh: 我经常跟别人说的，这些都是我吃了不少亏才悟出来的，就是你带着自己肯定对、对方肯定错的想法去开会，这本身就是不尊重人的表现，因为你根本不可能百分百确定嘛。总会有新的角度、新的信息冒出来的。
text_es: Mira, algo que siempre trato de enseñarle a la gente, y créeme que yo aprendí todo esto a golpes, es que es una falta de respeto total llegar a una reunión ya convencido de que tienes la razón y el otro está equivocado, porque la verdad es que no puedes estar seguro de eso. Siempre puede aparecer una perspectiva nueva, datos que no tenías.

text: So one of my favorite techniques here is this concept they call dream behind the complaint. Because you're right that we tend to not be that great always at really dreaming and envisioning and saying, "This is my dream of what I want out of life." That can sound really scary for people, but we're very good at complaining.
speaker: Kenneth Berger
context: Lenny asks Kenneth for specific techniques to help people identify what they want, particularly those who struggle with articulating their desires or tend to prioritize others' happiness over their own needs. Kenneth introduces his "dream behind the complaint" technique, explaining that while people often find it intimidating to articulate big dreams or visions, they're naturally skilled at identifying problems and frustrations. He suggests using complaints as a practical starting point for discovering underlying desires.
text_ko: 제가 여기서 좋아하는 기법 중 하나는 '불만 뒤의 꿈 (dream behind the complaint)'이라는 개념이에요. 말하신 대로 우리는 삶에서 진짜로 원하는 걸 마음껏 꿈꾸고 구체적으로 상상해서 '내가 원하는 삶은 이거야'라고 말하는 데 늘 능숙하지는 않아요. 그런 건 사람들한테 꽤 두렵게 느껴질 수 있는데, 대신 불평하는 건 참 잘하죠.
text_zh: 我特别喜欢用的一个方法叫做"投诉背后的梦想"(dream behind the complaint)。因为你说得对，我们往往不太擅长真正地去畅想和描绘，然后说"这就是我想要的人生"。这听起来可能让人觉得挺吓人的，但是抱怨这件事我们可在行了。
text_es: Una de mis técnicas favoritas es este concepto que llaman "el sueño detrás de la queja" (dream behind the complaint). Porque tienes razón en que no siempre somos muy buenos para realmente soñar y visualizar diciendo "Este es mi sueño de lo que quiero en la vida." Eso puede sonar muy intimidante para la gente, pero para quejarnos sí que somos buenísimos.

text: So I have a more expansive definition of no than most people, I think, because for me it's not a yes unless it's a hell yes. Because you really want enthusiastic consent. Not just, "Maybe, kinda. I'll try. We'll see. But yeah, absolutely, let's do this."
speaker: Kenneth Berger
context: Lenny asks Kenneth about overcoming the fear of hearing "no" when asking for what you want. Kenneth explains his philosophy around accepting responses, particularly his belief that anything short of enthusiastic agreement should be treated as a "no." He emphasizes the importance of seeking genuine, wholehearted commitment rather than settling for lukewarm or hesitant responses, as these often lead to problems later when people don't fully follow through on their commitments.
text_ko: 저는 대부분 사람들보다 '아니오'를 좀 더 넓게 보는 편이에요. 제게는 '헬 예스(hell yes)'가 아니면 예로 안 쳐요. 결국엔 진짜 열렬한 동의(enthusiastic consent)가 필요해요. '음… 아마도, 좀, 해볼게, 지켜보자' 같은 애매한 반응으론 충분하지 않아요.
text_zh: 我对"不"的定义可能比大多数人都要宽泛，因为在我看来，如果不是特别想做的事，那就是不做。你真的需要那种发自内心的认同，而不是那种"也许吧，差不多，试试看，再说吧"的态度。你要的是"好，没问题，咱们就这么干！"
text_es: Yo tengo una definición más amplia del "no" que la mayoría de la gente, creo, porque para mí no es un "sí" a menos que sea un "¡sí rotundo!" Porque realmente necesitas que la gente esté súper convencida. No solo un "A ver... tal vez. Lo intentaré. Ya veremos." Sino más bien "¡Sí, absolutamente, vamos a hacerlo!"

text: Part of really respecting them is respecting that they can make the choices they want and they're grownups enough that they can deal with the consequences of those choices.
speaker: Kenneth Berger
context: Kenneth discusses a common challenge he sees with "nice" founders who struggle to deliver difficult feedback or create consequences when team members aren't meeting expectations. He's explaining how these leaders often avoid creating accountability because they want to be liked and seen as kind. Kenneth argues that truly respecting people means acknowledging their autonomy to make decisions while also maintaining appropriate professional consequences for those choices.
text_ko: 진정으로 그들을 존중한다는 건, 그들이 자기 원하는 선택을 할 권리가 있고 그 선택의 결과를 스스로 감당할 수 있는 어른이라는 걸 인정해 주는 것도 포함돼요.
text_zh: 真正尊重他们，就是要相信他们有能力做自己想做的决定，而且他们都是成年人了，完全可以为自己的选择负责。
text_es: Parte de respetarlos de verdad es entender que pueden tomar sus propias decisiones y que son lo suficientemente adultos como para asumir las consecuencias de esas decisiones.
